posts.author: JadeKnight
posts.content:
I'm going to be playing SoU/HotU with two friends multiplayer.  I beat the NWN core campaign years ago (with no expansions) running an Elf Wizard/Ranger.

Details:
1) PvM
2) Level cap:  I'm looking for a build that optimizes at around level 25, but is playable the entire way.
3) Race preference:  No strong race preference.  I've traditionally leaned towards Elves/Half-Elves, but I'm happy to try other suggestions, especially for the sake of optimizing.
4) Classes:  We're playing a 3-player game, and one PC will be a Druid with a focus on summoning, and the other is going to be a Cleric or maybe Ranger.  So I don't want to be a Druid, and shouldn't be a summoning specialist.  I'm pretty much wide open for other classes, though I'd prefer at least a few spellcasting levels.
5) Melee preference:  I prefer a melee style that does not depend on micro-managing skills.
I'm open to pretty much anything: support roles, melee monsters, or ultimate spellcasters.  I'd love something with some prestige class mixed in, since I've never played a prestige class.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Welcome! We are happy you decided to stop by our little gathering.

25 levels isn't very far into epic so you should probably limit yourself to as little multiclassing as possible.  Have you checked through the Level 20 and Level 30 builds sections?  You may find an adequate design that can be better optimized for your Level 25 target.  The random section also contains a few ideas.

I'm not following your "melee style not micromanaging skills" comment.  Skills are never micromanaged, they are just allocated during creation and level-up.  What did you intend to convey?   No intense self-buffing perhaps.  Confusing.  Sry.

Anyway, going elf means a DEX build.  Half-elf could be either DEX or STR.  Your choice, but half-elf would cost a feat and around 30 skill points fewer over their human counterpart.

Are you planning to tank for your friends?  I recommend making one of your playmates an archer, either by DEXing ranger or a zen cleric.  Assuming the druid will be providing the spellcasting and summoning support, it would make sense to build a solid frontliner.  If you plan no tanking role, what was the plan for controlling the tide of flankers threatening your squad?

There are too many classes to consider going melee tank.  Monk, fighter and barb can all be multiclassed adequately with other classes, prestige or otherwise.  Pally somewhat less flexibility but still viable with sorc synergy.

Let's try to narrow this down a bit more, eh?  "Wide open" doesn't constitute a practical request that can be quantified to help you.

posts.author: JadeKnight
posts.content:
Thank you both for your responses!

I haven't played in about a decade, so I'm definitely a little rusty when it comes to builds.

I guess you could take my build request as having two portions (which I should have been more clear about):

1. What kind of role would be recommended for my character in a 3-party group with a Summoner Druid and a Ranger (I think the latter wants to go melee focus, but it's not entirely clear). They're probably going to hire henchmen, too. If I don't hire a henchman, would I still lose XP because they've got henchmen?

2. Within that role, what are some suggested builds? I have trawled the various build areas of this forum, and a big part of the issue is I'm not sure what kind of role I should take. I'm really ok with trying anything out; going with what's familiar isn't always the best way to enjoy a game. I could see going melee/tank, going support (bard or archer), or going for an arcane powerbuild.

Let me rephrase my melee comment: I don't prefer relying on single-round skills or spells in melee (I understand that True Strike is fairly powerful for a Spellsword, but I find myself struggling to know when the perfect time to use these kinds of one-shot melee skills/spells in RPG's).

Why is it a bad idea to multiclass for pre-epic builds?

We may well play all the way to 40 with additional campaigns, but I kind of think it would be fun to play a character that optimizes a little earlier; I understand that many builds, while playable at lower levels, optimize for level 30 or 40, and make sacrifices at earlier levels to get to that point. I'd prefer something that is as efficient of a power-build for the early epic levels, rather than something that continues to sacrifice to "max out" later. Also, since it's not clear I'll hit level 30 playing HotU, and I'm not positive that we'll play a community module afterwards, it made sense to me to try to optimize for level 25, which I'm likely to hit.

Once again, thank you for your help.

This would only work with robes and no shield.  One of the smaller shields wouldn't be so bad, but still has an associated spell failure.  In 25 levels, there is no way to achieve Autostill.  You could sub in Still Spell here for Extend but it would end up negating the advantage of empowered offense... kinda defeats the purpose of building a serious caster.

This is what I meant by not multiclassing a lot.  There is only a single Tumble dump at 23 which happens to coincide with a CHA boost.  Adding more frequent dumps will result in lowering the number of spells per day and offensive penetration (not a good idea without some boost via feats).  There is ALWAYS a trade-off and in this case would detract from your main power, spellcasting.

Besides the freebie CHA boost, I wanted to steer away from all XP penalty.  But that also comes at a cost, 2 borderline feats (Alertness/Iron Will) and some skill that you may not necessarily find use for.  You could sub in either monk or rogue at level 23 but suffer a penalty the last few levels.  If it doesn't matter, there is merit there but will also cost that point in CHA in the process.

You'd be using Div Shield constantly; Div Might, as needed.  Your playmates may not be able to pierce some DR but your sorc will always be able to, so DM's worth a lot in that respect.

In SoU, you end no higher than Level 12, just about the time you begin to take some metamagic to help you and your mates out.  They will likely appreciate your GMW and Flame Weapon buffs until CH2 of HotU when the uber weapons become available.  Empowered abilities will also boost their combat prowess.

Final build note:  I'm not recommending this build.  It's just been thrown together to illustrate a sort of cause-and-effect relationship between choice and in-game results.  You haven't expressed any concrete class combo preference so it's basically just thrown out at random.  However...
 
IMO It's actually pretty tough to play  a toon like this through SoU due to all the blasted, unpredictable alignment shifts in the chaos axis in that campaign.  I just finished testing a monk shifter through SoU and found I was unable to take more than a single monk level because some actions I took (still a total mystery to me!) moved my alignment permanently away from Lawful.  Pally will have the same issue and I'm not sure you will want to deal with that issue.  There is, however, a quest specific only to pallies in SoU.  That means more XP and goodies, right?

Any of the classes that enforce a rigid alignment prereq could potentially become just as unplayable (meaning: "unplayable as designed on paper") depending on the actions you chose and those could seem benign to many players.

Oh, and YES.  Your entire party will be penalized at the rate of approximately 10-15% XP per party member (each of the portraits that appears on the RH side of the screen).  So, not only will your mates be draining each other's kills but so will their henchfolk and summons.  For that reason, if you want to glean as much XP as possible, it's best to have your hench provide buffs and then dismiss them until the encounter has ended.  It can become tedious, though.  When I play, I tend to drag my hench along for moral support but leave them standing around waiting the rest of the time.

I do not envy your decision to attempt the SoU/HotU campaigns as multiplayer.  Our little group tried it several years back and, eventually, after much rescripting and manipulation via SQL, were able to get those modules to work okay for multiplayer.  The same goes for any of the so-called bridge modules and other SP extentions.  To play as multiplayer usually requires some serious customizations that only an experienced scripter and DB manager can accomplish in short order.  Sometimes the creator will advertise their modules as suitable for multiplayer and even furnish a maximum party size.  That is not the case for any of the Bioware-designed modules. Those are ALL intended for SP only by default. So Good Luck!

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Just as one example where HotU must be rewritten for MP that I recall...

When the defense of the Seer has been completed, only one PC (the current leader) will transport to the Valsharess throne room for the battle.  Consequently, the rest of the party doesn't register as killed by Meph at battle end so must join the leader in a new session to start Ch3.  We rewrote that part so that all PCs are treated as equals as part of the combat encounter in the throne room (and scaled Valsharess stats accordingly to party size), with leader needing to recall the dead mates in the reaper zone when he does the henchmen.  We also limited the total party henchmen to 2 mainly for flavor and interactions.  I say "we" but, in truth, I did little more than help test the changes and make suggestions about resolving problems.

The main problem throughout HotU is the transitions.  They were written to "pull" henchmen and summons through but not partymates.  The portals in the Reaper's realm can really cause havoc if your party tries to split up to cover territory faster.  The module, as written, can't keep track of PC-specific choices unless stored in a database and indexed according to each PC, which we finally did successfully.  Basically, as long as your party is willing to play follow-the-leader very closely, it will minimize screwing up the synchronization on most transitions.

At one time, there were PWs for all the Bioware campaigns available.  I haven't checked lately, but if they still exist, it's the most trouble-free method to play them on-line since the creators already built the synchronization database and debugged all the multiplayer issues.  In other words, all you need to do is log and play.  Not spend time trying to figure out how to adapt for MP.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
JadeKnight wrote:
Once again, thank you for your responses.  I understand that encounters scale in the Bioware campaigns, so even though dialogue might get a little weird, I'm assuming they should play ok multiplayer?  (I mean, the Prologue is specifically not recommended for multiplayer, but I find it runs fine if you ignore certain aspects of the dialogue.)  I'm also assuming the experience scales for MP?
You'll get more creature spawning but not higher CR.  CR will only change according the the average level of the party. In any case, it doesn't end up anywhere near proportional to the party size so you'll notice a HUGE difference in those occasions where you are forced to solo.
Anyone have any recommendations for handling loot in MP?  Drop and divvy, perhaps?
We used a widget that rolled dice to determine pecking order.  In absence of that, just assign a random order and rotate it on each "split".  We each sold our gems and incidentals, keeping track of the before-and-after personal gold inventory and deposited the delta gold plus all items into a handy chest.  The real picky groups chose the toon with the best Appraisal to do all the selling but we never bother.   Have someone designated with the best Lore ID all and then use your sequence, taking turns opening the chest and withdrawing 1 item each visit until all have been removed or the group decides that the remaining just be sold.  Then split the gold tally 3 ways, in your case.  We've found it helpful to order the chest inventory in a somewhat logical manner like armor first, then shields, then belts/helms/jewelry, then weapons, etc.... whatever makes the most sense to speed things up.  I guarantee you guys will forget who went first or last but just make your best guess
